xxl.core.cursors.sources

Class EmptyCursor<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.sources.EmptyCursor<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>

    public class EmptyCursor<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>
    An empty cursor contains no elements, i.e., every call to its hasNext method will return false. This class is useful when you have to return an iteration of some kind, but there are no elements the iteration points to. The class contains a static field, called DEFAULT_INSTANCE, which is similar to the design pattern, named Singleton, except that there are no mechanisms to avoid the creation of other instances. The intent of the design pattern is to ensure this class only has one instance, and provide a global point of access to it. For further information see: "Gamma et al.: DesignPatterns. Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software. Addision Wesley 1998."

    Example usage: 

         EmptyCursor<Integer> emptyCursor = new EmptyCursor<Integer>();
     
     emptyCursor.open();
 
     System.out.println("Is a next element available? " + emptyCursor.hasNext());
 
     emptyCursor.close();
 
     System.out.println("Is a next element available? " + EmptyCursor.DEFAULT_INSTANCE.hasNext());
    This example shows in two different ways that an empty cursor contains no elements:
    • A new instance of this class is directly created and the hasNext method is called.
    • The static field DEFAULT_INSTANCE, which returns an instance of this class, is used instead and then the hasNext method is called.

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_INSTANCE

        public static final EmptyCursor<Object> DEFAULT_INSTANCE
        This instance can be used for getting a default instance of an empty cursor. It is similar to the Singleton Design Pattern (for further details see Creational Patterns, Prototype in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides) except that there are no mechanisms to avoid the creation of other instances of this empty cursor.

    • Constructor Detail

      • EmptyCursor

        public EmptyCursor()
        Constructs a new empty cursor that contains no elements.

    • Method Detail

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the empty cursor has more elements.

      • nextObject

        protected E nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the empty cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

        Note, that this implementation is empty. So close does not have any effect. This is necessary to allow multiple references to EmptyCursor.DEFAULT_INSTANCE.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • supportsRemove

        public boolean supportsRemove()
        Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the empty cursor. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsRemove in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the remove operation is supported by the empty cursor, otherwise false.

      • supportsUpdate

        public boolean supportsUpdate()
        Returns true if the update operation is supported by the empty cursor. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:

        Overrides:

        Returns:

        public boolean supportsReset()
